text: hey guys thomas joseph here with another
kitchen conundrum this is actually a
grilling or barbecue conundrum and that
is in the summertime everybody likes to
make barbecue chicken but often times
before the chicken itself is cooked
thoroughly the exterior is blackened the
sauce it burns so I'm going to show you
how to avoid an outcome like this and
make perfectly moist barbecued chicken
with a beautiful barbecued glistening
exterior that you're going to be proud
to share with all your friends and
families this summer so the first step
in making barbecued chicken is to
actually give your chicken a good
rubdown with some spices salt and pepper
I have my favorite rub here you can use
whatever your favorite spice blend is
and give your chicken a liberal
sprinkling and what this does is it adds
to the flavor so you don't need to
overdo the barbecue sauce because you
have this spice rub imparting its flavor
onto the chicken so you can give good
coating to each side of your chicken
pieces now I'm using a whole chicken
that I've cut up into eight pieces you
can certainly cut this into 10 pieces if
you'd like or you could use just
drumsticks you could use thighs you
could use chicken breasts whatever this
method is all the same and so today I'm
grilling indoors so I have a grill pan
heating over medium high heat now if you
were doing this outside on your gas
grill or on your charcoal grill you want
to make sure that you have different
zones on your grill so you want to have
a high heat medium to high heat zone and
then a lower heat zone and so now with
this medium high heat grill pan that I'm
using I'm going to take a paper towel
and a little bit of a high heat oil like
a grapeseed safflower canola oil and
just oil the grades up and this helps
prevent the chicken from sticking to the
grates of the grill you can certainly do
this on your outdoor BBQ as well use a
pair of tongs though and not your hand
and now I'm going to place my chicken
pieces skin side down on the grill and
you don't want to touch or move the
chicken once you place it on the grates
so depending on what cut of chicken
you're using whether it's bone-in or
boneless that changes the cooking time
here once you get a nice caramelized
sear with wonderful grill marks move the
chicken over to the cooler part of your
grill so it's been about five minutes
I'm going to give the chicken a flip so
what you're looking for is some nice
grill marks but you don't want your
chicken to be charred spend about
another five minutes on this side here
and now if you're outside on your gas
grill or your charcoal grill move your
pieces of chicken over to the cooler
side of the grill over indirect heat so
that they can finish cooking through
without blackening on the outside
unfortunately I'm stuck here indoors and
I'm using a grill pan so my indirect
heat is going to be the oven so I have
my oven preheated to 375 degrees to
finish cooking the pieces of chicken so
the chicken has been in the oven for
about six to eight minutes on indirect
heat on your grill for about the same
amount of time almost completely cooked
through and this is the time now when
you want to brush with your favorite
barbecue sauce brushing within the last
few minutes of cooking really encourages
the barbecue sauce flavor to coat the
meat you'll get a nice caramelized crust
to your chicken pieces but it won't burn
and incinerate like this version I have
here so liberally coat the chicken
pieces with barbecue sauce and then this
goes back on indirect heat or into your
oven around five minutes until the sauce
is nice and caramelized so it's been
about five minutes the barbecue sauce is
nicely caramelized it's sticky sweet and
it's wonderful ready to eat so there you
have it three golden rules for
barbecuing chicken use a rub for extra
flavor start with direct heat first and
then Moo
to indirect heat to finish the cooking
and third brush barbecue sauce on in the
last five minutes to avoid burning and
you will have successful barbecue
chicken all summer long there you go
enjoy
you
